questions.question: Which of the following sorting algorithms always divides the array into two equal halves?

explanations.a: Quick Sort division depends on pivot selection and may be unbalanced.
explanations.b: Merge Sort always splits the array into two equal or nearly equal halves.
explanations.c: Bubble Sort does not divide the array.

questions.question: In Merge Sort, the array is recursively divided until each subarray contains:

explanations.b: Merge Sort does not stop at three elements.
explanations.c: A single element is considered already sorted.

questions.question: In Quick Sort using the Median of Three approach, the pivot is selected as the median of which elements?

explanations.a: The second element is not part of the Median-of-Three method.
explanations.b: Median of first, middle, and last helps avoid worst-case partitions.
explanations.c: The algorithm does not choose three middle elements.

questions.question: Why does the Median of Three technique improve Quick Sort performance?

answers.b: It avoids selecting extreme pivot values

explanations.a: Reduced recursion depth is a result, not the main goal.
explanations.b: Balanced pivot selection prevents highly unbalanced partitions.
explanations.c: Swapping is still required in Quick Sort.

questions.question: In the Median-of-Three technique, once arr[left] ≤ arr[center] ≤ arr[right] is ensured, where is the median element usually moved in the array?

explanations.a: The first index is not used as the pivot position.
explanations.b: The median is not kept in the middle for partitioning.
explanations.c: The median is moved to right − 1 to act as the pivot during partitioning.
explanations.d: The last index is reserved as a boundary element.
